Well, you could look at it as "a negative doesn't make sense for equilibrium" But I think it does in a weird way, Equilibrium is the number at which the population stays the the same, if it's positive you can only have less then or only slightly more then that. if it's negative you would need less then no creatures to stabilize the population. Which I think could be representative of the need of a hostile environment or an event that kills all the creatures then renders the environment hostile to them in order the reach equilibrium. Like mars has -1 normal humans, that's just how hostile it is. our replication rate would need edited or other wise changed along with our death rate in order to go there.

I mean I'm no biologist, that's just what comes to mind when I think "negative equilibrium" in this context.

1. I was born

Regarding the way you answered the question "Why do things exist?" with the statements "1. They started existing / They were born" and "2. They haven't stopped existing / They haven't died", how would you explain how things started existing? You even point out how unlikely it is for a bunch of atoms and molecules to come together to form a living thing, such as a rabbit. While you explain the maintenance of that existence by saying that living things can replicate themselves, this reasoning does not actually explain how the atoms and molecules come together to form a new living creature in the first place (by "new", I mean the very first of its kind), because there is no thing can replicate itself when it has not existed in the first place.

So just out of curiosity: how would you explain how a new thing - a first thing of its kind, living or non-living - could exist in the first place?

Treating life/biology like blackboxes and just focusing on how they act is basically how I visualize almost everything, by treating it’s constituent parts as little blackboxes that I don’t understand, I can then imagine how those boxes are wired between each other. So let’s take the brain for a moment, to me it’s basically a collection of ideas, the visual cortex in the back? It’s used for processing visual data? Well slap a big box around all of that and watch how it connects with the other parts! We don’t need to know how it works right now, just what it does. I also think of game code like this (not my games, just ones I play) so like in Mariokart, Luigi you say? I don’t need to know the specifics on how wiggly his nose has to be, just slap a big black box around him and watch how it interacts with the other parts. How does it keep track of who’s in first? I imagine a line through the center of every course, putting a black box around all the graphics, and every player’s position is moved to the closest point on that middle line, then all they have to do to find out who’s further along the line to figure out who’s first, second, last, you name it. That’s how I visualize things I can’t understand. We don’t need those pesky bonk physics, or those annoying character models, just the very center, everything else can be dropped into a blackbox and I don’t need to understand it.

My issue is not so much with science as it is with how people apply it. We all know science is good, but the problem comes in when people begin to move outside the realm of science, and yet use it to explain something beyond it. Let me use an example or an illustration, alright. If characters in a video game began to search for the cause of their existence, some of them would most likely do it very scientifically. They'd make use of the scientific method of observation, make conjectures (hypotheses), derive predictions from them as logical consequences, and then carry out experiments or empirical observations based on those predictions. They may do this as many times as possible, but we humans know they will never come to the truth of their existence, because they cannot measure, test and observe the humans who exists outside their world. We know there's nothing wrong with science. So, what's going on here? It's simple. The characters moved beyond the realm of science, yet still tried to make use of science. That's the problem. The same goes for the real world. Science only works insofar as you remain inside the feasible area, but as soon as you move beyond it, then you're running the risk of making serious mistakes... That's my problem with the theory of Evolution on the whole. I agree that mutations occur, species adapt and change and so forth, but you cannot create a "history" of species based on it and call it factual. You're moving outside the realm of science and that is dangerous to do. Or you can. Like, no one is stopping you, but you can't claim it as fact. Again, I suppose you can do that, but then it's on your head if you're wrong about it.

I like where you are going with these simulations.  To me, the math is a little off.  If the death rate is exactly 1 chance in 10, then mathematically the max population would end up at 10.0.  Any other value other than 10.0 would mean the death rate is not exactly 1 chance in 10.  This is a definitional problem.

I've watched all the videos, this first one, I oddly watched last. It's making me think about the Drake Equation (an equation for determining how many detectable civilizations may be out there in space), because it, in essence, contains parameters related to two of the variables from this simple example about existence: the birth rate (related to the fraction of planets with life that actually go on to develop intelligent life - civilizations) and the death rate (related to the length of time for which such civilizations release detectable signals into space). This simple example can explain the Fermi Paradox (i.e. Where are all the aliens?) - that the birth and death rates of such civilizations are roughly equal (and I know this also doesn't consider the "detectable" variable in the Drake equation).
Assuming that conjecture is roughly true, that points to a possible survival strategy for our civilization - replicate. I don't see any indication of that in the Drake equation, but this simple example would seem to indicate that your civilization (probably the whole ecosystem) would be wise to adopt a replication strategy for prolonged survivability. Of course, it would probably be pretty tough to replicate a viable ecosystem elsewhere if we destroy the current one before doing so.
I wonder if there is a tipping point past which you would no longer have the ability to replicate your civilization (ecosystem) once you have reached a certain point in using/destroying a limited set of resources (a planet) - an infertility point?

Quote from the next video: "We're going to make this model more realistic, by completely getting rid of that spontaneous birth chance, which we know is unrealistic for complex organisms"

.....This level of nonsense is painful. Things exist because they do, and evolution is possible because, once you accept things just spontaneously pop into existence, it's easy... and you can't even get a working math equation to demonstrate this?

The math is pretty simple, there's a better chance of Henry Ford's car factory forming in complete replication of all details (minus signs of life), spontaneously, than there is of forming even the simplest cell. It's more complicated than a car factory, it's not a ball of simplistic jelly as Darwin assumed. Trilobites, long considered the most simple form of land animals, are also discovered to have incredibly complex eyes.

Of course, that's assuming that DNA can survive in water or oxygenated environments, which it can't. And that's assuming amino acids bump into each other and bind together, which they don't. And a 0% chance divided by any number, no matter how fast your rabbits breed, is going to be 0.

As true as the models you show are, and as true as the concepts you demonstrate are, the proper question is "how do things exist?" not "why?" .

Why is a teleological question, that is, a question about the reason or point of something existing. From what I understand, this channel is not particularly dedicated to teleology, but to mechanics, or "how" things work. We must avoid conflating the two; good philosophy makes bad science, and vice versa.

Radiometric Dating (Ar-Ar Dating) is flawed because we don't know what Temperature Extremes or Pressure Levels that material was exposed to or placed under during its lifespan at that location where it was found. Temperature and Pressure alter the aging of all Biological Tissues and Materials, whether Animal, Vegetable, or Mineral.


We cannot tell what age a Fossilised creature's body is because of things like "Heatwaves", Cold Snaps", and other anomalies in weather patterns and extreme seasonal changes like Droughts and Floods, etc.


Whether we want to believe in the God of Jesus Christ and their "In the beginning, the Earth was without form and void..." story in the book of Genesis from the Holy Bible, or we want to believe there is no God and we are just really intelligent animals that like to wear Stylish Denim Jeans and Leather Boots after evolving from a pre-historic form of Ape....
Either way we decide to believe, it requires a certain level of scholarly investment and a lot of FAITH!


Either way, it involves some faith because neither way can be truly proven with honestly rigorous evidence that cannot be refuted... At this stage, I'm going to stick with the more likely story that there is Righteous and Creative God that likes to create living systems and creatures that Make Love & War and everything in between. I think:
If there is a higher birth chance than death chance, then number of creatures should increase.
If there is a lower birth chance than death chance, then the number of creatures should decrease.

If birth chance equals death chance, the number of creatures should stay the same by time.

N is not the number of creatures, but the multiplitator of how fast the creatures number changes by time.

This subject is pretty interesting to me. But i have to say its fundament is not really that complex to comprehend. Evolution is basically survival of life in any form. There is no trend, no better reiteration or advancement of any kind, we just see it that way because of the sample we observed in an isolated environment over a small period of time. Survival is random, what is the pinnacle of advancement right now might be totally worthless later. So a life form variation is better and superior until it's not.
There is that saying about in life death and taxes are the only certain things. I don't totally agree but i admit limits as a certainty, what begins must end, nothing is infinite. Thus an ascendent trend for evolution, as well as our Universe, can't continue going and going. There is an end, which surely means that evolution is random and what's better has no meaning or sense.

Sent by 3b1b, this is amazing I love it ! I am starting college next year and I am planning on concentrating on exactly the oveerlap between maths and biology so I love this! Would you consider posting the code for your simulations on GitHub? Thank you again for making such an amazing video :)
Real nice :^)

Love the simulations! The pace is good. I would say a big issue (not just with this video) is that quantitative modeling can be very abstract (e.g., how should I think of a birth rate? What part of the system does this control?). Personally, I would love to see graphs alongside the frame-by-frame simulations, since that's the standard presentation of this kind of data. Walk-throughs of the equations were OK, although I think you can spend more time helping people develop an intuition for why the equation makes sense. For example, around the 3:20 transition, looks like you assume people understand what you mean by equilibrium. Also, why should we expect the overall population to stay the same if birth rate = death rate? You should try to anticipate audience confusion. As an example, it's common for people to look at a graph of overall population and think that no more organisms are dying or being born because the overall number isn't changing, so explicitly walking through the system more would be great. Nice job :)
This is great! It takes a lot of effort to make biological formulas feel logical. Keep it up!
It's out of the scope of this series, but I'd be curious on the menu of other ways there are to answer the question of why things exist.

Now that you've talked a bit about reproduction, I think it could be fun to see a simulation where you start with n male creatures the same amount of male creatures and let them procreate where the first male procreates with n! (ex. Male 1 procreates with; Female 9, f 8, 7, 6.....) of the women and the same goes for the males, each male has to procreate with each female basically, and it's 50 50 (or 49/51) whether you get a female or a male, and the next generation does the same, but they're not allowed to procreate with anyone from the same forefathers, if you want to make it even more interesting/complicated you could do it so the next generation is allowed to procreate with maybe 2 generations back and of course no incest, you can also play with the amount of children they would get, maybe it could be influenced by what gender their offspring is, but it could also just be set after if you implement a chance for the infants to be stillborn and have them try procreating again and maybe set a limit there to how many times they will try, you could make the child death rate influenced by how old the person is getting, how many kids they've had, maybe make it a random genetic thing for some people to have a higher rate.

All in all my question is really just if you had 50 people split up 50 50 by gender, how many generations would it take before you wouldn't be able to procreate with anyone without it being incestual, the reason I started thinking about this was because of the Mars one mission where 50 contestants are sent to colonize Mars, and if you wanted to do that, how many generations would you 'realistically' be able to make, I know the environment probably isn't ideal, but if it's theoretical I'd just like to know, don't know how relevant this would be to this series you are making if you can fit it in somehow, but hopefully you'd consider at least looking at the concept, and maybe make just a separate series or a one time kind of video idk what this channel is going to be if you're even going to make more than just why do things exist series, good video and I'm excited for the next one.

You can play around with http://ncase.me/simulating/ to do similar simulations. The allowed models aren't quite the same, but you can get something similar by (e.g.) making a 20×20 grid, giving blank cells a 0.25% chance of turning into raindrops 💧, and raindrops a 10% chance of turning into blank spots. I can't get the "export" or "save" buttons working or I'd link to raindrop, star, and rabbit models.

Hey really nice video and exciting topic. A couple of thoughts, when I'm learning something, I really want to see things in perspective first, then move into details, so that I can put them together myself. Also, it'd help if I get excited about the topic before starting to learn about it.

Thanks again. I'm really looking forward to the rest of the series.
